author: Redacción Los Andes
title: Turquía: detienen a 32 sospechosos de preparar ataques yihadistas contra lugares de culto
text: Las autoridades turcas anunciaron este viernes la detención de 32 sospechosos, presuntos miembros del grupo yihadista Estado Islámico (EI), que se cree que estaban preparando atentados contra sinagogas e iglesias del país. Según una fuente de la seguridad turca consultada por medios locales, estas personas fueron detenidas durante redadas de las fuerzas de seguridad y de los servicios de inteligencia en nueve ciudades, entre ellas Estambul y Ankara, la capital. “Dos de los sospechosos (...) fueron a explorar a sinagogas e iglesias”, afirmó la fuente. Mencionó también a un tercer hombre que planeaba un ataque contra la embajada de Irak. Según esta fuente, los tres sospechosos son importantes miembros del grupo yihadista. La policía turca anunció la semana pasada una gran redada en 32 ciudades del país y la detención de más de 300 personas por presuntos vínculos con el EI. Los ataques a las comunidades judías y cristianas en el país árabe continúan en ascenso y han tenido un incremento notable desde los ataques de Hamás a Israel el pasado 7 de octubre. A propósito de ello, el presidente de Turquía, Recep Erdogan, declaró que no considera que Hamás sea un grupo terrorista y lo tildó de “grupo de liberación”, a la vez que acusó a Israel de atacar Gaza.

author: Justin Vigil-Zuniga
title: Hoops: Canyon holds off Castaic
text:
Canyon Cowboys boys’ basketball got its revenge on Friday night.
The Cowboys took down the hosting Castaic Coyotes, avenging a huge blowout tournament loss earlier in the season.
Canyon won the Foothill League road battle, 75-71, behind disciplined and physical defense, as well as a monster 33-point, four-rebound, two-block and two-steal performance from junior Eric Kubel.
The shooting guard spent time guarding every position, from Castaic’s guards to centers.
“My coach wants me to work on playing better defense and rebounding because I’ve been playing pretty well on the opposite end,” Kubel said. “But on the defensive side, I have some work to do. I’m working to become a better defender.”
The Cowboys (12-7, 2-3) were undersized, outnumbered and faced a tough road matchup against a team that had already beaten them with ease. However, Canyon’s extra effort on loose balls and rebounds led to a big disparity in the battle off the boards and pushed the Cowboys to victory.
Kubel came out of the gates hot and hit four of his six 3-pointers on the night in the first half. The junior has impressed Canyon coach Ali Monfared since transferring in last season.
“What you’re seeing from Eric right now is a product of the last eight or nine years,” Monfared said. “There’s no shortcuts to being great. He just does all the hard things you need to do and he’s been doing it for years. Kobe always talked about at some point you’re not going to out-rep me. Not only is he going to out-rep you, they’re quality game-like reps. In games, the offense is built around and rightfully so.”
Kubel hit back-to-back 3-balls in the first quarter before sophomore guard Isaac Yuhico drilled one more from behind the arc to put Canyon on a 9-0 run. The Cowboys took the lead early in the first quarter and didn’t trail for the remainder of the night.
Castaic senior Lucas Milan kept his team in the game throughout the night. Milan showed no issues breaking into the lane for layups or pull-up jumpers en route to his 32-point night.
“Lucas, he’s a warrior,” said Castaic coach Dominique Butler. “He’s the smallest guy on the floor, but plays with so much intensity, but it looks like he’s playing football out there. With the effort that he puts in grabbing rebounds, and then locking up somebody on the defensive end, too. He’s one of our leaders because he understands where we’re trying to go and how we’re trying to get there.”
Canyon had better energy in the first half, something that’s helped the team win six of its last seven games.
“We work really hard,” Kubel said. “That’s what helps us win, is our energy and our defense and our scrappiness. We lost like five games in a row at the beginning of the season. In fact, we got sick, too. And we just found our energy and our scrappiness really worked.”
Coincidentally, Butler felt his team came out flat in the first half before charging back into the game in the third quarter.
“It was a bad first half. We played with low energy, no effort,” Butler said. “In the second half, we kind of picked it up and understood the sense of urgency but it really shouldn’t get to that point. They gotta learn how to win these close games. Not every game is going to be a blowout. We have to be able to stay in the game and do things the right way to win the game.”
Milan did most of his damage in the second half, when the Coyotes (14-7, 0-5) exploded for 52 points. Castaic outscored Canyon, 24-12. The Coyotes were suddenly back in the game but a smart play design of a long, near full-court pass gave Kubel a clean look on the wing, where he drilled a buzzer beater to put Canyon up, 46-44, heading into the fourth quarter.
The game was physical on both ends, leading to free throws becoming a crucial part of the game down the stretch. Neither team shot fantastically from the line but Canyon was able to snag multiple offensive rebounds off misses, including two offensive putbacks from Collin Kusumi.
Kusumi, a senior, finished with 11 points, five rebounds, and was one of six Cowboys to have multiple blocks and steals. Junior guard Solomon Sims also played outstanding defense with four steals and a trio of blocks.
“These guys are learning right now that by working hard and being together, it doesn’t matter who’s taller than us,” Monfared said. “It doesn’t matter who’s more whatever than us, we’re going out together and we’re going to beat you as a team.”
Both teams clawed for the win as each had an answer for seemingly every opposing bucket. Kubel hit a big 3-ball in the fourth that was answered immediately by Castaic senior Christian Clark.
Yuhico was a vital part of Canyon staying out in front. The sophomore’s 3-pointer in the first quarter was his only made shot of the half. Yuhico delivered 10 of his 13 points in the second half and also finished with a pair of steals in just his second Foothill League game.
“(Yuhico’s) one of the smartest players I’ve ever coached as a sophomore,” Monfared said. “In the second half of the game, the ball was in his hands, and he’s just calm, cool and collected, and there’s not many 15-year-olds that can do that. The future’s so bright for that young man. He’s coachable. Tonight he controlled the pace of the game the way a senior would.”
Castaic was in striking distance down the final stretch but back-to-back turnovers cost the team a chance at a win and forced the Coyotes into the foul game.
Canyon avenged its 98-75 loss earlier in the season to Castaic. Monfared said the biggest differences between the two games was his Cowboys’ much-improved defense and better efficiency on the offensive end.
“We at times give up bunches of points or bunches of rebounds and when we continue to close that down, I think we’re going to be a scary thing to play in league,” Monfared said. “My focus as a coach is we’re getting better. That’s all I can really focus on as the kids buy in.”
Castaic’s first league win will have to wait another week, but the Coyotes have been on the cusp of the feat in numerous games this season. The newest Foothill League team has been dominant outside of league play but has just dropped tough matchups with Valencia, Golden Valley and now Canyon this season. Castaic will play Saugus next before heading into the second half of league play with big goals on the team’s mind.
Canyon has a lot to look forward to in the second half of league as well. The Cowboys are hot off the program’s first tournament win in 10 years and are winners of six of their last seven.
“I think the sky’s the limit,” Monfared said. “We’re still going to be humble. I still think there’s a lot we need to be better at. So, we’ll just keep cleaning that stuff up and make everything as tough as possible. Our motto on defense is ‘tough twos.’ Tough twos all day long and if we can continue to make every play like that, I continue to think we’re going to keep getting better and that’s the focus. Improvement, not results.”
The Cowboys have also played nearly every league game on the road and will get to play in their own gym for the majority of the rest of the schedule.
Both teams return to league action on Tuesday as Canyon returns home to host Hart, while Castaic heads to Saugus. Both games are set to tip off at 6:30 p.m.
“We just gotta keep doing the same things we’re doing,” Kubel said. “We’re gonna win big games this year.”

title: Follow Jesus' example and declutter your life
text: Satan has a way of keeping your eyes on things that don’t matter. How many of us are preoccupied with things happening in the world that have little to do with us? How many of us fear this coming year because of the political scene? In a nation built on the idea that cash is king, despite writing on that cash, “In God, we trust,” we self-medicate, got to get what we deserve, and keep up with the Joneses. And the more we have, the less we are. Jesus has a way of reaching us when we have nothing left. We seek possessions, promotions, experiences and attention. Yet, when all those things are stripped away from our lives, Jesus meets us there. Jesus is ever pursuing you. Jesus comes peacefully to offer you peace even when we seek it in all the wrong places. Fat bank accounts don’t grant peace. Jesus weeps over us when we can’t find peace - when we can’t see Him. Jesus wept over the city of Jerusalem. He saw lost and broken people desperately searching for a Messiah that would be their Prince of Peace. He was there, and they didn’t recognize or receive Him. They reject their king and still seek their King today, but He’s already come and gone. Jesus walked upon the temple mount and was sickened by the preying on interested people when they should have been praying for them. Luke tells us Jesus drove out those who sold. Jesus pushed away the things that got in the way of the house of prayer. Jesus wants you to pray. He wants to grant you peace and power in your place of worship, but the clutter has to be removed. All the extra books, sacrifices, commentaries, sermons, gadgets and stuff have to be laid aside so you can find Jesus. He meets us in a quiet and secret place. All the extra has to be put aside so you can take in His extravagance. Jesus knows the most important thing about you is your time with Him. So, don’t be like the temple of His day filled with extra business opportunities, schedules and hierarchy. Come to His throne room regularly, bare, expecting Him to grant you the power to tell the world about this great King you have found. He is good. He is returning to bring ultimate peace and power to those who believe This is good news, and we should build our existence upon Him. A firm foundation is worthy of our lives, and when we build on Jesus, He brings peace, promises to meet you in prayer, and grants the power to advance the Kingdom of Glory in this world. We realize how much we have in Jesus when He is all we have. 2024 is the year for you to put aside every other concern, possession, agenda, fear, hobby or habit if it’s in the way of becoming a house or a prayer. Find your house of prayer - He promises to meet you there. Subscribe to the Bertie Ledger-Advance

title: Revolutionizing Air Conditioning: Unveiling the Chau Device for Enhanced Efficiency and Energy Savings
text:
French Innovation: Caeli Energie Offers Eco-Pleasant Air Conditioning Alternative Published Feb. 26, 2025
As global sustainability efforts intensify, innovative solutions are emerging to tackle energy consumption and environmental impact. Among these is Caeli Energie , a ventilation device developed in France, poised to revolutionize conventional air conditioning. This system offers a more efficient and ecological approach to cooling, promising to transform how spaces are air-conditioned. The core principle lies in its ability to cool air without energy-intensive processes, achieving a significant reduction in temperature while minimizing its carbon footprint, making it an attractive alternative for both residential and commercial applications.
Traditional air conditioning systems frequently enough rely on compressors and refrigerant gases, contributing to significant energy consumption and environmental harm. Caeli Energie, though, employs an indirect evaporative cooling process, eliminating the need for these components. This innovative design not only reduces energy consumption but also contributes to the preservation of the surroundings by avoiding harmful cooling gases.
The core principle behind Caeli Energie lies in its ability to cool air without the energy-intensive processes of traditional systems. By utilizing evaporative cooling,the device achieves a significant reduction in temperature while minimizing its carbon footprint. This makes it an attractive alternative for both residential and commercial applications.
Key Characteristics of Caeli Energie Several key features distinguish Caeli Energie from conventional air conditioning systems:
Energy Efficiency: The device consumes less electricity, making it a cost-effective solution for cooling spaces. Sustainability: It does not rely on cooling gases that are harmful to the surroundings, aligning with global efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Simple Maintenance: The design facilitates easy cleaning and component replacement, reducing maintenance costs and downtime. Silent Operation: It operates with reduced noise levels, making it suitable for domestic and labor environments where noise pollution is a concern. The reduced noise levels are notably beneficial for environments where quiet is essential,such as offices,libraries,and residential spaces. traditional air conditioning systems can be disruptive due to the noise generated by compressors and fans. Caeli Energie’s silent operation ensures a more pleasant and productive environment.
The simplicity of maintenance is another significant advantage. Traditional air conditioning systems frequently require specialized technicians for repairs and maintenance. Caeli Energie’s design allows for easier access to components, simplifying the maintenance process and reducing the need for professional assistance.
The potential impact of Caeli Energie extends beyond individual households and businesses.By reducing energy consumption and eliminating harmful refrigerant gases, the device can contribute to broader efforts to combat climate change and promote enduring advancement. As governments and organizations around the world seek to reduce their carbon footprint,innovative solutions like Caeli Energie will play an increasingly vital role.
This technological advance promises to transform the air conditioning of spaces, offering a cheaper and ecological alternative to face high temperatures.
Could Evaporative Cooling Be the Future of Air Conditioning? An Exclusive Interview The world is heating up, and traditional air conditioning is contributing to the problem. But what if I told you there’s a game-changing solution that cools your space without harming the planet?
This is what Dr. Anya Sharma, a leading expert in lasting climate technologies at the Sorbonne University , had to say during an exclusive interview regarding Caeli Energie, the innovative French evaporative cooling system.
Interview Highlights World Today News: Dr. Sharma, the article highlights Caeli energie as a revolutionary eco-amiable air conditioning alternative. Can you elaborate on how it differs from traditional systems and its potential impact?
Dr. Sharma: Traditional air conditioning, as you know, primarily relies on vapor-compression refrigeration cycles. These systems use refrigerants, many of which are potent greenhouse gases, contributing considerably to global warming and ozone depletion.They also consume vast quantities of energy, increasing our reliance on fossil fuels. Caeli Energie, though, offers a significant departure from this model by employing indirect evaporative cooling. This means it cools the air without the need for harmful refrigerants or energy-intensive compressors. The impact is two-fold: reduced energy consumption and a dramatically decreased carbon footprint. This is a vital step towards more sustainable building design and operation.
World Today News: The article mentions energy efficiency and sustainability as key characteristics. Could you delve deeper into the technical aspects that make this possible?
Dr. Sharma: caeli Energie’s efficiency stems from its clever use of natural processes. Indirect evaporative cooling works by passing outside air over a water-saturated cooling medium. This evaporative process uses the latent heat of vaporization to lower the air’s temperature,creating a cooling effect. As it doesn’t rely on mechanical compression, the system consumes far less energy than traditional systems. The sustainability aspect comes from eliminating the need for synthetic refrigerants which, let’s not forget, have a significant global warming potential. The system’s operational simplicity further contributes to its environmental benefits.
World Today news: What are the practical implications of this technology for both residential and commercial applications? What are some potential use cases?
Dr. Sharma: For residential use, Caeli Energie offers a quieter, more energy-efficient, and environmentally responsible way to keep homes agreeable during hot weather. think of the potential for reduced energy bills, lowering your household’s environmental impact, and creating a healthier indoor environment. this technology is equally compelling for commercial applications.Offices,schools,hospitals – any environment sensitive to energy costs and environmental concerns – could benefit from Caeli Energie’s superior energy efficiency and reduced environmental impact. Consider a large office building implementing this system; the consequent decrease in electricity consumption and greenhouse gas emissions would be considerable. Many organizations and individuals are actively pursuing net-zero carbon emissions and Caeli Energie fits perfectly into this framework.
World Today News: Are there any drawbacks or challenges in implementing this technology on a wider scale? What are the potential obstacles?
Dr. Sharma: While the technology holds immense promise, scaling production and ensuring widespread adoption present some challenges. Initial investment costs might be higher compared to conventional systems, even though the long-term energy savings should compensate for this. The availability of suitable climate conditions – sufficient humidity and outdoor air quality – also plays a role in determining the system’s effectiveness and needs to be considered for large-scale implementation.Overcoming these requires government incentives,investment in research and growth,and public awareness campaigns highlighting the long-term benefits of sustainable climate solutions.
World Today News: What are your predictions for the future of evaporative cooling systems in the air conditioning market?
Dr. Sharma: I foresee a significant shift towards evaporative cooling technologies in the coming years. The growing concerns about climate change, coupled with rising energy prices, will drive demand for more sustainable cooling solutions. Caeli Energie, with its innovative approach and potential for scalability, has a significant opportunity to play a leading role in this transition.While challenges remain, improving system design, research into new approaches to evaporative cooling, and government support, especially creating incentives for energy saving equipment, will accelerate the adoption of this promising technology. Furthermore, this approach aligns with the global momentum towards net-zero commitments and represents a significant step toward a greener future.
world Today News: What final thought would you leave our readers with regarding caeli Energie and the future of sustainable cooling?
Dr. Sharma: The future of air conditioning is undeniably green. Caeli Energie’s success exemplifies the power of innovation in addressing climate concerns. By embracing technologies like indirect evaporative cooling and reducing our reliance on harmful refrigerants, we can enjoy comfortable temperatures without compromising the well-being of our planet.
